newsitem.title: DUBAI: Saudi United Sugar starts commissioning refinery.
newsitem.headline: Saudi United Sugar starts commissioning refinery.

text.p: Saudi Arabia's United Sugar Co has started commissioning the kingdom's first sugar refinery and commercial production is expected to begin in late March, its executive general manager said on Tuesday.
"Things are moving forward. We have begun commissioning part of the refinery. Everything is on schedule," Mohammad Kashgari told Reuters by telephone from the Red Sea port city of Jeddah.
"We expect commercial production probably in the second half of March," he said, adding that the white sugar will be sold mainly in the Saudi market.
Per capita consumption of sugar in the Arabian peninsula is among the world's highest at around 30 kg.

Commissioning of the 500,000 tonne annual capacity refinery means that imports of white sugar by Saudi Arabia -- a country of some 18 million people -- will drop sharply and the kingdom will become a predominantly raw sugar market.

Kashgari said during the year production will gradually increase to full capacity: "Production will be built gradually to full capacity. Our production for 1997 will not be 500,000 as we will be producing for nine months or so."
The refinery is 51 percent owned by Savola -- Saudi Arabia's biggest food group, 15 percent by Britain's Tate and Lyle Plc and the rest by Saudi sugar trading firms.
In late December United Sugar Co took delivery of its first cargo of raws from Australia's Queensland Sugar Corp.
Kashgari did not comment on future raws purchases.
